thread.title: BEE shares: a value play over the long term
thread.title_full: BEE shares: a value play over the long term - Moneyweb

author: Ray Mahlaka
title: BEE shares: a value play over the long term
text:
SANDTON – When the National Empowerment Fund’s Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) share scheme Asonge launched in 2007 with about 80 000 investors backing the scheme, very little was known then about empowerment shares.
At the time, the share scheme had little liquidity, as trade in the shares by black investors was minimal compared with the volume trade on the JSE.
Speaking at the 2015 Money Expo at Sandton Convention Centre on Friday, Craig Gradidge of Gradidge-Mahura Investments said that part of the problem was the lack of information on BEE shares when his financial planning company started operating in 2009.
“More and more people were talking about BEE shares. What we were seeing then was the lack of understanding around financial planning on BEE shares,” Gradidge said during his presentation on BEE shares and financial planning.
How times have changed given that most multinational companies now offer BEE investments to historically disadvantaged individuals.
Today, Gradidge-Mahura Investments manages BEE investments worth R500 million.
Gradidge said when embarking on any investments, one should factor in the ability of an asset class to generate an income; consider the tax implications of any investment; the ability of an investment to generate cash (liquidity); the size of the investment; costs of maintaining the investment; flexibility of investment; risk for the potential capital loss; and geared returns.
Gradidge said some BEE shares do have liquidity and others don’t. “Some BEE shares give returns and others not so much. Some of the shares are tax efficient if they give out big dividends.”
When compared with other asset classes such as rental property, Gradidge said with BEE shares, there are possibilities of geared returns and transaction costs are low. He warns: “But they are very risky because of how they are structured.”
When most BEE shares start they initially have debt locked into the scheme and with the potential of interest rates rising, the debt can run into billions, which can destroy a lot of value in the schemes.
“BEE deals have debt to them and that allows you to see that if the company should dissolve then how much value will come to you as an investor,” Gradidge said.
Some schemes have lock-in periods as to when investors into a BEE share scheme can sell their shares to other black investors.
Comparing share schemes, Gradidge said the move by MTN’s empowerment share scheme MTN Zakhele to the JSE’s BEE board will give it more liquidity. It currently trades on an Over The Counter (OTC) platform.
This is after the Financial Services Board issued a directive, which plans to put a stop to unlicensed exchanges – extending to OTC platforms. While Sasol Inzalo, Gradidge suggests, is sensitive to the share price of its holding company, petrochemical group Sasol Limited.
The big picture when it comes to investing in BEE shares, Gradidge recommends is don’t guess which will be the best opportunity, but investors should empower themselves with information. “Try to understand what asset you are buying. You can get decent returns over the long term.”
